awd_titl_txt: Concurrent Multiscale Moving-Window Scheme for Shock Wave Interaction with Material Microstructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Shock waves occur in a material when it is subjected to extreme pressure and temperature changes in a very short time. This is commonly observed in applications when a material is subjected to high speed impact. The need to design advanced materials resistant to shock damage has driven the research into the material's response to shock waves from the nano- and micro-meter scales to the large application scale. This grant, co-funded by the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), supports fundamental research into the multiscale response of the material when subjected to shock loading. It will provide new knowledge on how shock waves interact with material features at the micro and nano scales leading to deformation and failure at the macroscale. The research will accelerate the design of advanced materials with superior shock resistant properties for n aerospace, automotive, infrastructure and defense industries. Additionally, the project will provide opportunities to educate and train graduate and undergraduate students in the interdisciplinary areas of materials science, computational mechanics, and applied physics and mathematics through research in the laboratory. The PI will also engage in outreach activities related to science and engineering to K-12 students through university programs. 

Shock response of the material is multiscale in nature, introducing defects such as voids and dislocations at the microscale and cracks and plastic deformation at the macroscale. This work develops a concurrent multiscale method, with coexisting atomistic and continuum domains, to study shock wave propagation through a material and its interaction with material microstructure. State of the art concurrent multiscale schemes are unable to capture high speed dynamic processes such as shock waves and moving atomistic regions. The framework uses a control volume based moving-window scheme, where the atomistic domain follows a moving shock wave, to circumvent issues with current state of the art schemes. Using this new framework, the work will study microstructural evolution, shock induced defect generation, and the influence of microstructural features such as grain boundaries on shock resistance properties, e.g., spall strength. The framework will be systematically validated against existing experimental data on shock induced defect generation available in the literature.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the fundamental questions related to the multiscale response of the material when subjected to shock loading. Shock waves occur in a material when it is subjected to extreme pressure and temperature changes in a very short time. This is commonly observed in applications (such as defense and aerospace environments) when a material is subjected to high speed impact. The primary goal was to develop and use a novel multiscale method to investigate how shock waves travel in a material and how it interacts with the internal structure of the material. The outcomes of this project are summarized below:

1. Intellectual Merit

This research provided new insights into how the shock wave evolves and develops a structure as it moves through a material, resulting in damage and defects. Notably, this work resulted in fundamental relation between shock pressures and speeds (referred to as linear equation of state) for different materials. This work also demonstrated how these relations change depending on the direction in which the shock propagates (referred to as anisotropy of Hugoniot relations). As the shock wave moves through the material, it develops a stable structure (experimentally quantified using shock thickness or rise time). Shock structure has been linked to the formation of defects in the material. This project provided valuable insights into shock structure development and its dependence on the direction in which it travels. 

This project developed new methodologies for studying multiscale response of a material with moving features (like shock waves). The framework, connecting high-resolution (atomic) to low-resolution (continuum) regions, advanced the state-of-the-art by a) tracking a moving shock wave for a long time over a large domain which is computationally prohibitive by conventional techniques, b) seamlessly connecting and transferring information (waves and defects) from regions of high resolution to lower resolution, and c) adaptively moving the high resolution areas of the framework to regions of interest. 

2. Broader Impacts

The project engaged four graduate students (three Ph.D. students and one M.S. student) and five undergraduate students (three in Aerospace Engineering, one in Materials Science, and one in Computer Science) in mechanics of materials and materials science research. Aside from research opportunities, the project supported students in their professional development through conference presentations, poster presentations, invited seminars, and applications to competitive scholarships. The project also supported collaboration with scientists at Los Alamos National Laboratory and Army Research Laboratory resulting in mentors from the labs serving on the students' advisory committee. 

Outreach activities included participation in Auburn University events, such as E-Day and AE-Alumni Day. The PI and students organized hands-on activities and displays for E-Day, an event that annually hosts 4,000 K-12 students, parents, and educators. The PI also organized displays for AE-Alumni Day, which focuses on Aerospace Engineering alumni, including industry professionals and national lab scientists. Graduate students involved in the project presented their work to industry professionals at the Engineering Research Showcase, an annual event in Huntsville, AL, organized by the College of Engineering.

3. Dissemination of Results

The findings from this project were disseminated through four journal publications, nine conference presentations, and several invited presentations by the PI and graduate students. Results were also shared with industry professionals through poster presentations at AE-Alumni Day and the Engineering Research Showcase.

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2025
Modified by: Vinamra Agrawal
